Award.AbstractNarration:
A successful product requires synthesizing explicit and tacit knowledge from domain experts to create a solution that is easily produced, meets customer needs, and is financially viable in the marketplace. Ambiguity in product specifications and miscommunications among stakeholders during the early design phases create downstream changes that incur significant financial and engineering costs to re-work. Achieving a common vision across disciplines and employing agile development and prototyping is essential to ensuring delivery of a timely and cost-effective product. Software-based solutions for product design collaboration and prototyping have been explored for traditional product design processes; however the unique characteristics of emerging wearable, pervasive, and internet-of-things products require new solutions. These products tightly couple physical and computation elements to create novel human-computer interactions that constantly sense and adapt to user needs. To create these systems, design teams must simultaneously balance the computational and physical constraints of the design, and understand how users will interact with the product over its life time.

The proposed tool, called ?Storycoding? addresses these challenges by providing design teams an accessible sketch-based interface to collaborate and express product ideas for novel pervasive computing products. Storycoding actively interprets a design team's storyboards to ensure relevant computational and user interaction requirements have been specified. Storycoding can automatically generate source code for a product, allowing more rapid prototype generation during the ideation and design phases of product development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Effective Internet-of-Things products require a balance of physical and computational aspects throughout their design process.  However, design teams often struggle to successfully synthesize design constraints that range from physical form factor to human-computer interaction to software, particularly early in the design process as the teams define a product's specification.  The purpose of this project, Storycoding, was to address these challenges by providing design teams with an accessible sketch-based interface to collaborate and express product ideas.. Storycoding actively interprets a design team’s storyboards using natural language processing, user-supplied annotation, and layout analysis to ensure relevant computational and user interaction requirements have been specified. Using a model-driven engineering approach, Storycoding can automatically generate source code for a product, allowing more rapid prototype generation during the ideation and design phases of product development.

The major result of our customer discovery interviews was that we discovered that our target customers did not want to automatically generate code. The engineers did not trust generated code and thoughtthat they could write better code themselves. But instead of generating code, we found that we could automatically generate requirements so that the design firms and their clients could more quickly achieve a shared understanding. In particular, our approach can generate design requirements for teams that use an agile software development process. 

The intellectual merit of this project includes the technical aspects of extracting design requirements from a storyboard using natural langage processing and layout analysis.  

The broader impacts include the potential commercial impact of improving the agile software development process, particularly for Internet-of-Things products. The borader impacts also include enabling more rapid and more reliable development of products that will be integrated into people's daily lives across a wide variety of applications, including wellness, fitness, transportation, emergency response, smart buildings, and entertainment.
